added_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2014-03-22 06:14+0000\n"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_arch_provision.xml:296(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:855(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_arch_compute_nodes.xml:393(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_arch_storage.xml:561(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_arch_network_design.xml:383(title)msgid "OpenStack is founded on a thriving community that is a source of help and welcomes your contributions. This chapter details some of the ways you can interact with the others involved."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:20(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:21(para) msgid "There are several avenues available for seeking assistance. The quickest way is to help the community help you. Search the Q&A sites, mailing list archives, and bug lists for issues similar to yours. If you can't find anything, follow the directions for reporting bugs or use one of the channels for support, which are listed below."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:27(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:29(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:30(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:40(para) msgid "General list: openstack@lists.openstack.org. The scope of this list is the current state of OpenStack. This is a very high-traffic mailing list, with many, many emails per day."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:50(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:61(para) msgid "Development list: openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org. The scope of this list is the future state of OpenStack. This is a high-traffic mailing list, with multiple emails per day."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:71(para) msgid "We recommend that you subscribe to the general list and the operator list, although you must set up filters to manage the volume for the general list. You'll also find links to the mailing list archives on the mailing list wiki page where you can search through the discussions."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:76(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:86(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:87(para) msgid "As an operator, you are in a very good position to report unexpected behavior with your cloud. Since OpenStack is flexible, you may be the only individual to report a particular issue. Every issue is important to fix, so it is essential to learn how to easily submit a bug report."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:92(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:97(para) msgid "Once you have a Launchpad account, reporting a bug is as simple as identifying the project or projects that are causing the issue. Sometimes this is more difficult than expected, but those working on the bug triage are happy to help relocate issues if they are not in the right place initially." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:104(para) msgid "Report a bug in nova (https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:114(para) msgid "Report a bug in swift (https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:119(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:125(para) msgid "Report a bug in glance (https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:130(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:136(para) msgid "Report a bug in keystone (https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:141(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:147(para) msgid "Report a bug in neutron (https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:152(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:158(para) msgid "Report a bug in cinder (https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:163(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:169(para) msgid "Report a bug in horizon (https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:174(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:179(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:185(para) msgid "To write a good bug report, the following process is essential. First, search for the bug to make sure there is no bug already filed for the same issue. If you find one, be sure to click on \"This bug affects X people. Does this bug affect you?\" If you can't find the issue, then enter the details of your report. It should at least include:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:193(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:198(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:202(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:206(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:210(para) msgid "Portions of your log files so that you include only relevant excerpts."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:214(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:217(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:221(para) msgid "In the bug comments, you can contribute instructions on how to fix a given bug, and set it to Triaged. Or you can directly fix it: assign the bug to yourself, set it to In progress, branch the code, implement the fix, and propose your change for merging. But let's not get ahead of ourselves, there are bug triaging tasks as well."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:228(title) msgid "Confirming and Prioritizing"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:229(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:237(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:241(para) msgid "Once you have reproduced the issue (or are 100 percent confident that this is indeed a valid bug) and have permissions to do so, set:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:246(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:250(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:254(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:257(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:260(para) msgid "Critical if the bug prevents a key feature from working properly (regression) for all users (or without a simple workaround) or results in data loss."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:267(para) msgid "High if the bug prevents a key feature from working properly for some users (or with a workaround)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:273(para) msgid "Medium if the bug prevents a secondary feature from working properly." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:278(para) msgid "Low if the bug is mostly cosmetic." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:283(para) msgid "Wishlist if the bug is not really a bug but rather a welcome change in behavior."msgid "If the bug contains the solution, or a patch, set the bug status to Triaged."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:292(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:293(para) msgid "At this stage, a developer works on a fix. During that time, to avoid duplicating the work, the developer should set:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:297(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:301(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:304(para) msgid "When the fix is ready, the developer proposes a change and gets the change reviewed."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:308(title) msgid "After the Change Is Accepted"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:309(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:313(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:317(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:321(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:325(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:332(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:333(para) msgid "Since you've made it this far in the book, you should consider becoming an official individual member of the community and join the OpenStack Foundation (https://www.openstack.org/join/). The OpenStack Foundation is an independent body providing shared resources to help achieve the OpenStack mission by protecting, empowering, and promoting OpenStack software and the community around it, including users, developers, and the entire ecosystem. We all share the responsibility to make this community the best it can possibly be, and signing up to be a member is the first step to participating. Like the software, individual membership within the OpenStack Foundation is free and accessible to anyone."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:347(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:348(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:350(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:355(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:367(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:378(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:387(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:388(para) msgid "As a community, we take security very seriously and follow a specific process for reporting potential issues. We vigilantly pursue fixes and regularly eliminate exposures. You can report security issues you discover through this specific process. The OpenStack Vulnerability Management Team is a very small group of experts in vulnerability management drawn from the OpenStack community. The team's job is facilitating the reporting of vulnerabilities, coordinating security fixes and handling progressive disclosure of the vulnerability information. Specifically, the team is responsible for the following functions:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:401(para) msgid "Vulnerability management: All vulnerabilities discovered by community members (or users) can be reported to the Team."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:406(para) msgid "Vulnerability tracking: The Team will curate a set of vulnerability related issues in the issue tracker. Some of these issues are private to the Team and the affected product leads, but once remediation is in place, all vulnerabilities are public."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:413(para) msgid "Responsible disclosure: As part of our commitment to work with the security community, the team ensures that proper credit is given to security researchers who responsibly report issues in OpenStack."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:419(para) msgid "We provide two ways to report issues to the OpenStack Vulnerability Management Team, depending on how sensitive the issue is:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:424(para) msgid "Open a bug in Launchpad and mark it as a \"security bug.\" This makes the bug private and accessible to only the Vulnerability Management Team."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:429(para) msgid "If the issue is extremely sensitive, send an encrypted email to one of the team's members. Find their GPG keys at OpenStack Security (http://www.openstack.org/projects/openstack-security/)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:437(para) msgid "You can find the full list of security-oriented teams you can join at Security Teams (http://wiki.openstack.org/SecurityTeams). The vulnerability management process is fully documented at Vulnerability Management (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/VulnerabilityManagement)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:447(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:448(para) msgid "In addition to this book, there are many other sources of information about OpenStack. The OpenStack website (http://www.openstack.org) is a good starting point, with OpenStack Docs (http://docs.openstack.org) and OpenStack API Docs (http://api.openstack.org) providing technical documentation about OpenStack. The OpenStack wiki contains a lot of general information that cuts across the OpenStack projects, including a list of recommended tools (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OperationsTools ). Finally, there are a number of blogs aggregated at Planet OpenStack (http://planet.openstack.org)."msgid "OpenStack follows a six month release cycle, typically releasing in April/May and October/November each year. At the start of each cycle, the community gathers in a single location for a design summit. At the summit, the features for the coming releases are discussed, prioritized, and planned. The shows an example release cycle with dates showing milestone releases, code freeze, and string freeze dates along with an example of when the summit occurs. Milestones are interim releases within the cycle that are available as packages for download and testing. Code freeze is putting a stop to adding new features to the release. String freeze is putting a stop to changing any strings within the source code."msgid "To take the first path, you can modify the OpenStack code directly. Learn how to contribute (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/How_To_Contribute), follow the code review workflow (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritWorkflow), make your changes, and contribute them back to the upstream OpenStack project. This path is recommended if the feature you need requires deep integration with an existing project. The community is always open to contributions and welcomes new functionality that follows the feature-development guidelines. This path still requires you to use DevStack for testing your feature additions, so this chapter walks you through the DevStack environment."msgid "For the second path, you can write new features and plug them in using changes to a configuration file. If the project where your feature would need to reside uses the Python Paste framework, you can create middleware for it and plug it in through configuration. There may also be specific ways of customizing a project such as creating a new scheduler driver for Compute or a custom tab for the dashboard."msgid "This chapter focuses on the second path for customizing OpenStack by providing two examples for writing new features. The first example shows how to modify Object Storage (swift) middleware to add a new feature, and the second example provides a new scheduler feature for OpenStack Compute (nova). To customize OpenStack this way you need a development environment. The best way to get an environment up and running quickly is to run DevStack within your cloud."msgid "To create a development environment, you can use DevStack. DevStack is essentially a collection of shell scripts and configuration files that builds an OpenStack development environment for you. You use it to create such an environment for developing a new feature."msgid "Boot an instance from the dashboard or the nova command-line interface (CLI) with the following parameters."msgid "Log in and set up DevStack. Here's an example of the commands you can use to set up DevStack on a virtual machine."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:88(para) msgid "Log in to the instance."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:89(replaceable)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:89(replaceable)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:91(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:93(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:95(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:97(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:101(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:107(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:109(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:111(para) msgid "Set some permissions you can use to view the DevStack screen later."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:113(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:118(para) msgid "Edit the localrc configuration file that controls what DevStack will deploy. Copy the example localrc file at the end of this section. (See .)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:123(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:125(para) msgid "When the stack script is done, you can open the screen session it started to view all of the running OpenStack services."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:128(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by 0 to go to the first window."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:139(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:148(para) msgid " is a useful program for viewing many related services at once. For more information, see the GNU screen quick reference. (http://aperiodic.net/screen/quick_reference)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:158(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:163(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:206(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:207(para) msgid "OpenStack Object Storage, known as swift when reading the code, is based on the Python Paste (http://pythonpaste.org/) framework. The best introduction to its architecture is A Do-It-Yourself Framework (http://pythonpaste.org/do-it-yourself-framework.html). Because of the swift project's use of this framework, you are able to add features to a project by placing some custom code in a project's pipeline without having to change any of the core code."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:217(para) msgid "Imagine a scenario where you have public access to one of your containers, but what you really want is to restrict access to that to a set of IPs based on a whitelist. In this example, we'll create a piece of middleware for swift that allows access to a container from only a set of IP addresses, as determined by the container's metadata items. Only those IP addresses that you explicitly whitelist using the container's metadata will be able to access the container."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:226(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:231(para) msgid "When you join the screen session that stack.sh starts with screen -r stack, you see a screen for each service running, which can be a few or several depending on how many services you configured DevStack to run."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:235(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:239(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:242(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:584(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:247(para) msgid "key* The keystone service."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:252(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:594(para) msgid "horizon The horizon dashboard web application."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:257(para) msgid "s-{name} The swift services."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:263(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:265(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:269(para) msgid "Change to the directory where Object Storage is installed."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:271(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:275(para) msgid "Copy the code in into ip_whitelist.py. The following code is a middleware example that restricts access to a container based on IP address as explained at the beginning of the section. Middleware passes the request on to another application. This example uses the swift \"swob\" library to wrap Web Server Gateway Interface (WSGI) requests and responses into objects for swift to interact with. When you're done, save and close the file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:285(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:380(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:388(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:393(para) msgid "To plug this middleware into the swift Paste pipeline, you edit one configuration file, /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:397(para) msgid "Find the [filter:ratelimit] section in /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf, and copy in the following configuration section after it."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:412(para) msgid "Find the [pipeline:main] section in /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf, and add ip_whitelist after ratelimit to the list like so. When you're done, save and close the file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:421(para) msgid "Restart the Swift Proxy service to make swift use your middleware. Start by switching to the swift-proxy screen."msgid "Press CtrlA followed by 3."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:426(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:790(para) msgid "Press CtrlC to kill the service."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:427(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:791(para) msgid "Press Up Arrow to bring up the last command." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:428(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:792(para) msgid "Press Enter to run it."msgid "Test your middleware with the swift CLI. Start by switching to the shell screen and finish by switching back to the swift-proxy screen to check the log output."msgid "Press CtrlA followed by 0." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:438(para) msgid "Make sure you're in the devstack directory." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:441(para) msgid "Source openrc to set up your environment variables for the CLI." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:444(para) msgid "Create a container called middleware-test." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:446(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by 3 to check the log output." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:449(para)msgid "These two statements are produced by our middleware and show that the request was sent from our DevStack instance and was allowed." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:456(para) msgid "Test the middleware from outside DevStack on a remote machine that has access to your DevStack instance." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:461(para) msgid "Install the keystone and swift clients on your local machine." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:463(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:468(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by 3 to check the log output. Look at the swift log statements again, and among the log statements you'll see the lines:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:477(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:482(para) msgid "Back in your DevStack instance on the shell screen, add some metadata to your container to allow the request from the remote machine."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:486(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by 0."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:491(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:495(para) msgid "Now try the command from again and it succeeds. There are no objects in the container, so there is nothing to list, however there is also no error to report."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:503(para) msgid "Functional testing like this is not a replacement for proper unit and integration testing, but it serves to get you started."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:505(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:515(para) msgid "When your middleware is done, we encourage you to open source it and let the community know on the OpenStack mailing list. Perhaps others need the same functionality. They can use your code, provide feedback, and possibly contribute. If enough support exists for it, perhaps you can propose that it be added to the official swift middleware (https://github.com/openstack/swift/tree/master/swift/common/middleware)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:525(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:526(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:539(para) msgid "To create a scheduler, you must inherit from the class nova.scheduler.driver.Scheduler. Of the five methods that you can override, you must override the two methods marked with an asterisk (*) below."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:546(code)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:551(code)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:556(code)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:560(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:564(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:568(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:575(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:578(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:589(para) msgid "key The keystone service."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:599(para) msgid "n-{name} The nova services."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:604(para) msgid "n-sch The nova scheduler service."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:610(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:613(para) msgid "The code for OpenStack lives in /opt/stack, so go to the nova directory and edit your scheduler module. Change to the directory where nova is installed:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:617(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:621(para) msgid "The code in is a driver that will schedule servers to hosts based on IP address as explained at the beginning of the section. Copy the code into ip_scheduler.py. When you're done, save and close the file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:628(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:754(para) msgid "There is a lot of useful information in context, request_spec, and filter_properties that you can use to decide where to schedule the instance. To find out more about what properties are available, you can insert the following log statements into the schedule_run_instance method of the scheduler above."msgid "To plug this scheduler into nova, edit one configuration file, /etc/nova/nova.conf."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:772(para) msgid "Find the scheduler_driver config and change it like so."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:777(para) msgid "Restart the nova scheduler service to make nova use your scheduler. Start by switching to the n-sch screen."msgid "Press CtrlA followed by 9."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:785(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by N until you reach the n-sch screen." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:796(para) msgid "Test your scheduler with the nova CLI. Start by switching to the shell screen and finish by switching back to the n-sch screen to check the log output." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:802(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by 0." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:806(para) msgid "Make sure you're in the devstack directory." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:809(para) msgid "Source openrc to set up your environment variables for the CLI." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:812(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:814(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:818(para) msgid "Switch back to the n-sch screen. Among the log statements, you'll see the line:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:823(para) msgid "Functional testing like this is not a replacement for proper unit and integration testing but it serves to get you started."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:826(para) msgid "A similar pattern can be followed in other projects that use the driver architecture. Simply create a module and class that conform to the driver interface and plug it in through configuration. Your code runs when that feature is used and can call out to other services as necessary. No project core code is touched. Look for a \"driver\" value in the project's .conf configuration files in /etc/<project> to identify projects that use a driver architecture." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:834(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:844(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:845(para) msgid "The dashboard is based on the Python Django (https://www.djangoproject.com/) web application framework. The best guide to customizing it has already been written and can be found at Building on Horizon (http://docs.openstack.org/developer/horizon/topics/tutorial.html)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:856(para) msgid "When operating an OpenStack cloud, you may discover that your users can be quite demanding. If OpenStack doesn't do what your users need, it may be up to you to fulfill those requirements. This chapter provided you with some options for customization and gave you the tools you need to get started."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_backup_recovery.xml:202(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_log_monitor.xml:763(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:626(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_network_troubleshooting.xml:966(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:833(title)msgid "This chapter helps you set up your working environment and use it to take a look around your cloud."msgid "Using the OpenStack dashboard for Administration"msgid "As a cloud administrative user, you can use the OpenStack dashboard to create and manage projects, users, images, and flavors. Users are allowed to create and manage images within specified projects and to share images depending on the Image Service configuration. Typically, the policy configuration allows admin users only to set quotas and create and manage services. The dashboard provides an Admin tab with a System Panel and Identity Panel. These interfaces give you access to system information and usage as well as to settings for configuring what end-users can do. Refer to the OpenStack Admin User Guide for detailed how-to information about using the dashboard as an admin user."msgid "Command-Line Tools"msgid "We recommend using a combination of the OpenStack command-line interface (CLI) tools and the OpenStack dashboard for administration. Some users with a background in other cloud technologies may be using the EC2 Compatibility API, which uses naming conventions somewhat different from the native API. We highlight those differences."msgid "We strongly suggest that you install the command-line clients from the Python Package Index (PyPI) (https://pypi.python.org/) instead of from the distribution packages. The clients are under heavy development, and it is very likely at any given time that the version of the packages distributed by your operating-system vendor are out of date."msgid "If you support the EC2 API on your cloud, you should also install the \"euca2ools\" package or some other EC2 API tool so that you can get the same view your users have. Using EC2 API-based tools is mostly out of the scope of this guide, though we discuss getting credentials for use with it."msgid "Administrative Command-Line Tools"msgid "There are also several *-manage command-line tools. These are installed with the project's services on the cloud controller and do not need to be installed separately:"msgid "Unlike the CLI tools mentioned above, the *-manage tools must be run from the cloud controller, as root, because they need read access to the config files such as /etc/nova/nova.conf and to make queries directly against the database rather than against the OpenStack API endpoints."msgid "You must have the appropriate credentials if you want to use the command-line tools to make queries against your OpenStack cloud. By far the easiest way to obtain authentication credentials to use with command-line clients is to use the OpenStack dashboard. From the top-right navigation row, select Project, then Access & Security, then API Access to access the user settings page where you can set your language and timezone preferences for the dashboard view. This action displays two buttons, Download OpenStack RC File and Download EC2 Credentials, which let you generate files that you can source in your shell to populate the environment variables the command-line tools require to know where your service endpoints and your authentication information are. The user you logged in to the dashboard dictates the filename for the openrc file, such as demo-openrc.sh. When logged in as admin, the file is named admin-openrc.sh."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:166(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:193(para) msgid "This does not save your password in plain text, which is a good thing. But when you source or run the script, it prompts you for your password and then stores your response in the environment variable OS_PASSWORD. It is important to note that this does require interactivity. It is possible to store a value directly in the script if you require a noninteractive operation, but you then need to be extremely cautious with the security and permissions of this file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:203(para) msgid "EC2 compatibility credentials can be downloaded by selecting Project, then Access & Security, then API Access to display the Download EC2 Credentials button. Click the button to generate a zip file with server x509 certificates and a shell script fragment. Create a new directory in a secure location because these are live credentials containing all the authentication information required to access your cloud identity, unlike the default user-openrc. Extract the zip file here. You should have cacert.pem, cert.pem, ec2rc.sh, and pk.pem. The ec2rc.sh is similar to this:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:236(para) msgid "To put the EC2 credentials into your environment, source the ec2rc.sh file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:240(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:241(para) msgid "The command-line tools can be made to show the OpenStack API calls they make by passing the --debug flag to them. For example:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:245(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:249(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:256(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:259(para) msgid "Configuring OS_CACHE causes the command-line tool to authenticate on each and every interaction with the cloud. This can assist with working around this scenario. However, it increases the time taken to run commands and also the load on the server."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:266(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:267(para) msgid "Underlying the use of the command-line tools is the OpenStack API, which is a RESTful API that runs over HTTP. There may be cases where you want to interact with the API directly or need to use it because of a suspected bug in one of the CLI tools. The best way to do this is to use a combination of cURL (http://curl.haxx.se/) and another tool, such as jq (http://stedolan.github.com/jq/), to parse the JSON from the responses."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:280(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:283(para) msgid "Your credentials are a combination of username, password, and tenant (project). You can extract these values from the openrc.sh discussed above. The token allows you to interact with your other service endpoints without needing to reauthenticate for every request. Tokens are typically good for 24 hours, and when the token expires, you are alerted with a 401 (Unauthorized) response and you can request another token."msgid "Pick a service endpoint from your service catalog, such as compute. Try a request, for example, listing instances (servers)."msgid "The -s flag used in the cURL commands above are used to prevent the progress meter from being shown. If you are having trouble running cURL commands, you'll want to remove it. Likewise, to help you troubleshoot cURL commands you can include the -v flag to show you the verbose output. There are many more extremely useful features in cURL; refer to the man page for all the options."msgid "As an administrator, you have a few ways to discover what your OpenStack cloud looks like simply by using the OpenStack tools available. This section gives you an idea of how to get an overview of your cloud, its shape, size, and current state."msgid "The output shows that there are five compute nodes and one cloud controller. You see a smiley face, such as :-) which indicates that the services are up and running. If a service is no longer available, the :-) symbol changes to XXX. This is an indication that you should troubleshoot why the service is down."msgid "If you are using cinder, run the following command to see a similar listing:"msgid "You can also use the Identity Service (keystone) to see what services are available in your cloud as well as what endpoints have been configured for the services."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:393(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:418(para) msgid "The preceding output has been truncated to show only two services. You will see one service block for each service that your cloud provides. Note how the endpoint domain can be different depending on the endpoint type. Different endpoint domains per type are not required, but this can be done for different reasons, such as endpoint privacy or network traffic segregation."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:426(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:431(title) msgid "Diagnose Your Compute Nodes"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:432(para) msgid "You can obtain extra information about virtual machines that are running—their CPU usage, the memory, the disk I/O or network I/O—per instance, by running the command with a server ID:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:437(para) msgid "The output of this command varies depending on the hypervisor because hypervisors support different attributes. The following demonstrates the difference between the two most popular hypervisors. Example output when the hypervisor is Xen: While the command should work with any hypervisor that is controlled through libvirt (e.g., KVM, QEMU, LXC), it has been tested only with KVM. Example output when the hypervisor is KVM:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:481(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:482(para) msgid "To see which fixed IP networks are configured in your cloud, you can use the command-line client to get the IP ranges."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:492(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:498(para) msgid "This output shows that two networks are configured, each network containing 255 IPs (a /24 subnet). The first network has been assigned to a certain project, while the second network is still open for assignment. You can assign this network manually, or it is automatically assigned when a project launches its first instance."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:504(para) msgid "To find out whether any floating IPs are available in your cloud, run:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:511(para) msgid "Here, two floating IPs are available. The first has been allocated to a project, while the other is unallocated."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:515(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:516(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:537(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:559(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:566(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:567(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:582(para) msgid "Unfortunately, this command does not tell you various details about the running instances, such as what compute node the instance is running on, what flavor the instance is, and so on. You can use the following command to view details about individual instances:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:590(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:620(para) msgid "This output shows that an instance named was created from an Ubuntu 12.04 image using a flavor of m1.small and is hosted on the compute node c02.example.com."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:627(para)
deleted_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2014-03-21 06:20+0000\n"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_arch_provision.xml:296(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:832(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_arch_compute_nodes.xml:393(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_arch_storage.xml:561(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_arch_network_design.xml:383(title)msgid "OpenStack is founded on a thriving community which is a source of help, and welcomes your contributions. This section details some of the ways you can interact with the others involved."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:21(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:22(para) msgid "There are several avenues available for seeking assistance. The quickest way to is to help the community help you. Search the Q&A sites, mailing list archives, and bug lists for issues similar to yours. If you can't find anything, follow the directions for Reporting Bugs in the section below or use one of the channels for support below."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:29(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:31(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:32(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:42(para) msgid "General list: openstack@lists.openstack.org. The scope of this list is the current state of OpenStack. This is a very high traffic mailing list, with many, many emails per day."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:52(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:63(para) msgid "Development list: openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org. The scope of this list is the future state of OpenStack. This is a high traffic mailing list, with multiple emails per day."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:73(para) msgid "We recommend you subscribe to the general list and the operator list, although you must set up filters to manage the volume for the general list. You'll also find links to the mailing list archives on the mailing list wiki page where you can search through the discussions."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:79(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:89(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:90(para) msgid "As an operator, you are in a very good position to report unexpected behavior with your cloud. As OpenStack is flexible, you may be the only individual to report a particular issue. Every issue is important to fix so it is essential to learn how to easily submit a bug report."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:96(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:101(para) msgid "Once you have a Launchpad account, reporting a bug is as simple as identifying the project, or projects that are causing the issue. Sometimes this is more difficult than expected, but those working on the bug triage are happy to help relocate issues if their not in the right place initially."msgid "Report a bug in Nova (https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+filebug)" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:114(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:119(para) msgid "Report a bug in Swift (https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:124(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:130(para) msgid "Report a bug in Glance (https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:135(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:141(para) msgid "Report a bug in Keystone (https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:146(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:152(para) msgid "Report a bug in Neutron (https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:157(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:163(para) msgid "Report a bug in Cinder (https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:168(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:174(para) msgid "Report a bug in Horizon (https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+filebug)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:179(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:184(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:190(para) msgid "To write a good bug report, the following process is essential. First, search for the bug to make sure there is no bug already filed for the same issue. If you find one, be sure to click on \"This bug affects X people. Does this bug affect you?\" If you can't find the issue then enter the details of your report. It should at least include:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:199(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:204(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:208(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:212(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:216(para) msgid "Read and understood your log files so you only include relevant excerpts."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:220(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:223(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:227(para) msgid "In the bug comments, you can contribute instructions on how to fix a given bug, and set it to Triaged. Or you can directly fix it: assign the bug to yourself, set it to In progress, branch the code, implement the fix, and propose your change for merging into trunk. But let's not get ahead of ourselves, there are bug triaging tasks as well."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:236(title) msgid "Confirming & Prioritizing"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:237(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:245(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:249(para) msgid "Once you have reproduced the issue (or are 100% confident that this is indeed a valid bug) and have permissions to do so, set:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:254(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:258(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:262(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:265(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:268(para) msgid "Critical if the bug prevents a key feature from working properly (regression) for all users (or without a simple workaround) or result in data loss"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:276(para) msgid "High if the bug prevents a key feature from working properly for some users (or with a workaround)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:282(para) msgid "Medium if the bug prevents a secondary feature from working properly"msgid "Low if the bug is mostly cosmetic"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:293(para) msgid "Wishlist if the bug is not really a bug, but rather a welcome change in behavior" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:299(para) msgid "If the bug contains the solution, or a patch, set the bug status to Triaged" msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:304(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:305(para) msgid "At this stage, a developer works on a fix. During that time, to avoid duplicating the work, they should set:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:310(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:314(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:317(para) msgid "When the fix is ready, they propose and get the change reviewed."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:320(title) msgid "After the Change is Accepted"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:321(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:325(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:329(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:333(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:337(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:344(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:345(para) msgid "Since you've made it this far in the book, you should consider becoming an official individual member of the community and Join The OpenStack Foundation (https://www.openstack.org/join/). The OpenStack Foundation is an independent body providing shared resources to help achieve the OpenStack mission by protecting, empowering, and promoting OpenStack software and the community around it, including users, developers and the entire ecosystem. We all share the responsibility to make this community the best it can possibly be and signing up to be a member is the first step to participating. Like the software, individual membership within the OpenStack Foundation is free and accessible to anyone."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:363(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:364(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:366(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:371(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:383(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:394(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:403(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:404(para) msgid "As a community, we take security very seriously and follow a specific process for reporting potential issues. We vigilantly pursue fixes and regularly eliminate exposures. You can report security issues you discover through this specific process. The OpenStack Vulnerability Management Team is a very small group of experts in vulnerability management drawn from the OpenStack community. Their job is facilitating the reporting of vulnerabilities, coordinating security fixes and handling progressive disclosure of the vulnerability information. Specifically, the Team is responsible for the following functions:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:418(para) msgid "Vulnerability Management: All vulnerabilities discovered by community members (or users) can be reported to the Team."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:423(para) msgid "Vulnerability Tracking: The Team will curate a set of vulnerability related issues in the issue tracker. Some of these issues are private to the Team and the affected product leads, but once remediation is in place, all vulnerabilities are public."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:431(para) msgid "Responsible Disclosure: As part of our commitment to work with the security community, the team ensures that proper credit is given to security researchers who responsibly report issues in OpenStack."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:438(para) msgid "We provide two ways to report issues to the OpenStack Vulnerability Management Team depending on how sensitive the issue is:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:443(para) msgid "Open a bug in Launchpad and mark it as a 'security bug'. This makes the bug private and accessible to only the Vulnerability Management Team."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:449(para) msgid "If the issue is extremely sensitive, send an encrypted email to one of the Team's members. Find their GPG keys at OpenStack Security (http://www.openstack.org/projects/openstack-security/)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:458(para) msgid "You can find the full list of security-oriented teams you can join at Security Teams (http://wiki.openstack.org/SecurityTeams). The Vulnerability Management process is fully documented at Vulnerability Management (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/VulnerabilityManagement)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:470(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upstream.xml:471(para) msgid "In addition to this book, there are many other sources of information about OpenStack. The OpenStack website (http://www.openstack.org) is a good starting point, with OpenStack Docs (http://docs.openstack.org) and OpenStack API Docs (http://api.openstack.org) providing technical documentation about OpenStack. The OpenStack wiki contains a lot of general information that cuts across the OpenStack projects including a list of recommended tools (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OperationsTools ). Finally, there are a number of blogs aggregated at Planet OpenStack (http://planet.openstack.org)."msgid "OpenStack follows a six month release cycle, typically releasing in April/May and October/November each year. At the start of each cycle, the community gathers in a single location for a design summit. At the summit, the features for the coming releases are discussed, prioritized, and planned. The figure shows an example release cycle with dates showing milestone releases, code freeze, and string freeze dates along with an example of when the summit occurs. Milestones are interim releases within the cycle that are available as packages for download and testing. Code freeze is putting a stop to adding new features to the release. String freeze is putting a stop to changing any strings within the source code."msgid "To take the first path, you can modify the OpenStack code directly. Learn How To Contribute (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/How_To_Contribute), follow the Code Review Workflow (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritWorkflow), make your changes, and contribute them back to the upstream OpenStack project. This path is recommended if the feature you need requires deep integration with an existing project. The community is always open to contributions and welcomes new functionality that follows the feature development guidelines. This path still requires you to use DevStack for testing your feature additions so this section walks you through the DevStack environment."msgid "For the second path, you can write new features and plug them in using changes to a configuration file. If the project where your feature would need to reside uses the Python Paste framework, you can create middleware for it and plug it in through configuration. There may also be specific ways of customizing a project such as creating a new scheduler driver for Compute or a custom tab for the Dashboard."msgid "This chapter focuses on the second path for customizing OpenStack by providing two examples for writing new features. The first example shows how to modify Object Storage (swift) middleware to add a new feature, and the second example provides a new scheduler feature for OpenStack Compute (nova). To customize OpenStack this way you'll need a development environment. The best way to get an environment up and running quickly is to run DevStack within your cloud."msgid "To create a development environment you can use DevStack. DevStack is essentially a collection of shell scripts and configuration files that will build an OpenStack development environment for you. We will use it to create such an environment for developing a new feature."msgid "Boot an instance from the Dashboard or the nova command-line interface (CLI) with the following parameters."msgid "Login and set up DevStack. Here's an example of the commands you can use to set up DevStack on a virtual machine."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:86(para) msgid "Login to the instance."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:87(replaceable)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:87(replaceable)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:89(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:91(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:93(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:95(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:99(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:105(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:107(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:109(para) msgid "Set some permissions so you can view the DevStack screen later."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:111(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:116(para) msgid "Edit the localrc configuration file that controls what DevStack will deploy. Copy in the example localrc file at the end of this section."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:120(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:122(para) msgid "When the stack script is done you can open the screen session it started to view all of the running OpenStack services."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:124(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by pressing 0 to go to the first window."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:134(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:143(para) msgid " is a useful program for viewing many related services at once. For more information, see GNU screen quick reference. (http://aperiodic.net/screen/quick_reference)"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:154(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:159(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:202(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:203(para) msgid "OpenStack Object Storage, known as swift when reading the code, is based on the Python Paste (http://pythonpaste.org/) framework. The best introduction to its architecture is A Do-It-Yourself Framework (http://pythonpaste.org/do-it-yourself-framework.html). Due to the swift project's use of this framework, you are able to add features to a project by placing some custom code in a project's pipeline without having to change any of the core code."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:214(para) msgid "Imagine a scenario where you have public access to one of your containers, but what you really want is to restrict access to that to a set of IPs based on a whitelist. In this example we'll create a piece of middleware for Swift that allows access to a container from only a set of IP addresses, as determined by the container's metadata items. Only those IP addresses that you explicitly whitelist using the container's metadata will be able to access the container."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:223(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:228(para) msgid "When you join the screen session that stack.sh starts with screen -r stack, you see a screen for each service running, which can be a few or several depending on how many services you configured Devstack to run."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:233(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:237(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:240(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:571(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:245(para) msgid "key* The Keystone service."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:250(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:581(para) msgid "horizon The Horizon dashboard web application."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:255(para) msgid "s-{name} The Swift services."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:261(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:263(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:267(para) msgid "Change to the directory where Swift is installed."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:269(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:273(para) msgid "Copy the following code into ip_whitelist.py. The following code is a middleware example that restricts access to a container based on IP address as explained at the beginning of the section. Middleware passes the request on to another application. This example uses the swift \"swob\" library to wrap Web Server Gateway Interface (WSGI) requests and responses into objects for swift to interact with. When you're done, save and close the file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:275(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:370(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:378(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:383(para) msgid "To plug this middleware into the Swift Paste pipeline you edit one configuration file, /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:387(para) msgid "Find the [filter:ratelimit] section in /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf and copy in the following configuration section after it."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:401(para) msgid "Find the [pipeline:main] section in /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf and add ip_whitelist after ratelimit to the list like so. When you're done, save and close the file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:409(para) msgid "Restart the Swift Proxy service to make Swift use your middleware. Start by switching to the swift-proxy screen." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:413(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by pressing 3." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:414(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:769(para) msgid "Press CtrlC to kill the service." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:415(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:770(para) msgid "Press Up Arrow to bring up the last command." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:416(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:771(para) msgid "Press Enter to run it." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:420(para) msgid "Test your middleware with the Swift CLI. Start by switching to the shell screen and finish by switching back to the swift-proxy screen to check the log output."msgid "Press CtrlA followed by pressing 0."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:426(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:782(para) msgid "Make sure you're in the devstack directory."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:429(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:785(para) msgid "Source openrc to setup your environment variables for the CLI."msgid "Create a container called middleware-test." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:434(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by pressing 3 to check the log output."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:440(para) msgid "These 2 statements are produced by our middleware and show that the request was sent from our DevStack instance and was allowed." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:445(para) msgid "Test the middleware from outside of DevStack on a remote machine that has access to your DevStack instance." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:450(para) msgid "Install the Keystone and Swift clients on your local machine." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:458(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by pressing 3 to check the log output. Look at the Swift log statements again and among the log statements you'll see the lines:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:465(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:470(para) msgid "Back in your DevStack instance on the shell screen add some metadata to your container to allow the request from the remote machine."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:474(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by pressing 0."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:476(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:480(para) msgid "Now try the command from again and it succeeds. There are no objects in the container so there is nothing to list, however there is also no error to report."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:487(para) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:798(para) msgid "Functional testing like this is not a replacement for proper unit and integration testing but it serves to get you started."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:490(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:500(para) msgid "When your middleware is done, we encourage you to open source it and let the community know on the OpenStack mailing list. Perhaps others need the same functionality. They can use your code, provide feedback, and possibly contribute. If enough support exists for it, perhaps you can propose that it be added to the official Swift middleware (https://github.com/openstack/swift/tree/master/swift/common/middleware)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:511(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:512(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:525(para) msgid "To create a scheduler you must inherit from the class nova.scheduler.driver.Scheduler. Of the five methods that you can override, you must override the two methods indicated with a \"*\" below."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:533(code)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:538(code)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:543(code)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:547(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:551(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:555(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:562(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:565(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:576(para) msgid "key The Keystone service."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:586(para) msgid "n-{name} The Nova services."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:591(para) msgid "n-sch The Nova scheduler service."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:598(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:601(para) msgid "The code for OpenStack lives in /opt/stack so go to the nova directory and edit your scheduler module. Change to the directory where Nova is installed:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:605(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:609(para) msgid "The following code is a driver that will schedule servers to hosts based on IP address as explained at the beginning of the section. Copy the following code into ip_scheduler.py. When you're done, save and close the file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:615(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:739(para) msgid "There is a lot of useful information in context, request_spec, and filter_properties that you can use to decide where to schedule the instance. To find out more about what properties are available you can insert the following log statements into the schedule_run_instance method of the scheduler above." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:753(para) msgid "To plug this scheduler into Nova edit one configuration file, /etc/nova/nova.conf." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:758(para) msgid "Find the scheduler_driver config and change it like so." msgstr "" #: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:763(para) msgid "Restart the Nova scheduler service to make Nova use your scheduler. Start by switching to the n-sch screen."msgid "Press CtrlA followed by pressing 9."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:768(para) msgid "Press CtrlA followed by pressing N until you reach the n-sch screen."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:775(para) msgid "Test your scheduler with the Nova CLI. Start by switching to the shell screen and finish by switching back to the n-sch screen to check the log output."msgid "Press CtrlA followed by pressing 0."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:787(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:789(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:793(para) msgid "Switch back to the n-sch screen. Among the log statements you'll see the line:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:801(para) msgid "A similar pattern can be followed in other projects that use the driver architecture. Simply create a module and class that conform to the driver interface and plug it in through configuration. Your code runs when that feature is used and can call out to other services as necessary. No project core code is touched. Look for a \"driver\" value in the project's conf configuration files in /etc/<project> to identify projects that use a driver architecture."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:810(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:820(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:821(para) msgid "The Dashboard is based on the Python Django (https://www.djangoproject.com/) web application framework. The best guide to customizing it has already been written and can be found at Building on Horizon (http://docs.openstack.org/developer/horizon/topics/tutorial.html)."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_customize.xml:833(para) msgid "When operating an OpenStack cloud you may discover that your users can be quite demanding. If OpenStack doesn't do what your users need, it may be up to you to fulfill those requirements. This chapter provided you with some options for customization and gave you the tools you need to get started."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_backup_recovery.xml:202(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_log_monitor.xml:763(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:629(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_network_troubleshooting.xml:966(title) ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_projects_users.xml:833(title)msgid "This section helps you set up your working environment and use it to take a look around your cloud."msgid "Using the OpenStack Dashboard for Administration"msgid "As a cloud administrative user, you can use the OpenStack Dashboard to create and manage projects, users, images, and flavors as an admin user. Users are allowed to create anad manage images within specified projects and share images, depending on the Image Service configuration. Typically the policy configuration only allows admin users to set quotas and create and manage services. The Dashboard provides an Admin tab with a System Panel and Identity Panel. These interfaces give you access to system information and usage as well as configuring what end-users can do. Refer to the OpenStack Admin User Guide for detailed how-to information about using the Dashboard as an admin user."msgid "Command Line Tools"msgid "We recommend using a combination of the OpenStack command line interface (CLI) tools and the OpenStack Dashboard for administration. Some users with a background in other cloud technologies may be using the EC2 Compatibility API, which uses somewhat different naming conventions from the native API. We highlight those differences."msgid "We strongly suggest that you install the command-line clients from the Python Package Index (PyPI) (https://pypi.python.org/) instead of from the distribution packages. The clients are under heavy development and it is very likely at any given time the version of the packages distributed by your operating system vendor are out of date."msgid "If you support the EC2 API on your cloud you should also install the \"euca2ools\" package or some other EC2 API tool so you can get the same view your users have. Using EC2 API based tools is mostly out of the scope of this guide, though we discuss getting credentials for use with it."msgid "Administrative Command Line Tools"msgid "There are also several *-manage command line tools. These are installed with the project's services on the cloud controller and do not need to be installed separately:"msgid "Unlike the CLI tools mentioned above, the *-manage tools must be run from the cloud controller, as root, because they need read access to the config files such as /etc/nova/nova.conf and make queries directly against the database rather than against the OpenStack API endpoints."msgid "You must have the appropriate credentials if you wish to use the command line tools to make queries against your OpenStack cloud. By far the easiest way to obtain authentication credentials to use with command line clients is to use the OpenStack Dashboard. From the top right navigation row, select Project, then Access & Security, then API Access to access the user settings page where you can set your language and timezone preferences for the dashboard view. This action displays two buttons, Download OpenStack RC File and Download EC2 Credentials, which let you to generate files you can source in your shell to populate the environment variables the command line tools need to know where your service endpoints are as well as your authentication information. The user you logged into the dashboard dictates the filename for the openrc file, such as demo-openrc.sh. When logged in as admin, the file is named admin-openrc.sh."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:164(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:191(para) msgid "This does not save your password in plain text, which is a good thing. But when you source or run the script, it prompts for your password and then stores your response in the environment variable OS_PASSWORD. It is important to note that this does require interactivity. It is possible to store a value directly in the script if you require a noninteractive operation, but you then need to be extremely cautious with the security and permissions of this file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:201(para) msgid "EC2 compatibility credentials can be downloaded from the Project, then Access & Security, then API Access to display the Download EC2 Credentials button. Click the button to generate a zip file with server x509 certificates and a shell script fragment. Create a new directory in a secure location because these are live credentials containing all the authentication information required to access your cloud identity, unlike the default user-openrc. Extract the zip file here. You should have cacert.pem, cert.pem, ec2rc.sh and pk.pem. The ec2rc.sh is similar to this:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:234(para) msgid "To put the EC2 credentials into your environment source the ec2rc.sh file."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:238(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:239(para) msgid "The command line tools can be made to show the OpenStack API calls they make by passing the --debug flag to them. For example:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:243(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:247(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:254(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:257(para) msgid "Configuring OS_CACHE causes the command line tool to authenticate on each and every interaction with the cloud. This can assist with working around this scenario. However, it increases the time taken to run commands and also the load on the server."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:264(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:265(para) msgid "Underlying the use of the command line tools is the OpenStack API, which is a RESTful API that runs over HTTP. There may be cases where you want to interact with the API directly or need to use it because of a suspected bug in one of the CLI tools. The best way to do this is use a combination of cURL (http://curl.haxx.se/) and another tool to parse the JSON, such as jq (http://stedolan.github.com/jq/), from the responses."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:279(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:282(para) msgid "Your credentials are a combination of username, password, and tenant (project). You can extract these values from the openrc.sh discussed above. The token allows you to interact with your other service endpoints without needing to re-authenticate for every request. Tokens are typically good for 24 hours, and when the token expires, you are alerted with a 401 (Unauthorized) response and you can request another token."msgid "Pick a service endpoint from your service catalog, such as compute, and try out a request like listing instances (servers)."msgid "The -s flag used in the cURL commands above are used to prevent the progress meter from being shown. If you are having trouble running cURL commands, you'll want to remove it. Likewise, to help you troubleshoot cURL commands you can include the -v flag to show you the verbose output. There are many more extremely useful features in cURL, refer to the man page for all of the options."msgid "As an administrator, there are a few ways to discover what your OpenStack cloud looks like simply by using the OpenStack tools available. This section gives you an idea of how to get an overview of your cloud, its shape, size, and current state."msgid "The output shows that there are five compute nodes and one cloud controller. You see a smiley face like :-) which indicates that the services are up and running and functional. If a service is no longer available, the :-) changes to an XXX. This is an indication that you should troubleshoot why the service is down."msgid "If you are using Cinder, run the following command to see a similar listing:"msgid "You can also use the Identity Service (Keystone), to see what services are available in your cloud as well as what endpoints have been configured for the services."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:394(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:419(para) msgid "The output above has been truncated to show only two services. You will see one service block for each service that your cloud provides. Note how the endpoint domain can be different depending on the endpoint type. Different endpoint domains per type are not required, but can be done for different reasons such as endpoint privacy or network traffic segregation."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:427(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:432(title) msgid "Diagnose your compute nodes"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:433(para) msgid "You can obtain extra information about the running virtual machines: their CPU usage, the memory, the disk I/O or network I/O, per instance, by running the command with a server ID:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:438(para) msgid "The output of this command will vary depending on the hypervisor, as they support different attributes. The following demonstrates the difference between the two most popular hypervisors. Example output when the hypervisor is Xen: While the command should work with any hypervisor that is controlled through libvirt (e.g., KVM, QEMU, LXC), it has only been tested with KVM. Example output when the hypervisor is KVM:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:483(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:484(para) msgid "To see what Fixed IP networks are configured in your cloud, you can use the command-line client to get the IP ranges."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:493(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:499(para) msgid "This output shows that two networks are configured, each network containing 255 IPs (a /24 subnet). The first network has been assigned to a certain project while the second network is still open for assignment. You can assign this network manually or it is automatically assigned when a project launches their first instance."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:506(para) msgid "To find out if any floating IPs are available in your cloud, run:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:513(para) msgid "Here, two floating IPs are available. The first has been allocated to a project while the other is unallocated."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:518(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:519(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:540(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:562(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:569(title)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:570(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:585(para) msgid "Unfortunately this command does not tell you various details about the running instances, such as what compute node the instance is running on, what flavor the instance is, and so on. You can use the following command to view details about individual instances:"#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:593(para)#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:623(para) msgid "The above output shows that an instance named was created from an Ubuntu 12.04 image using a flavor of m1.small and is hosted on the compute node c02.example.com."#: ./doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_lay_of_land.xml:630(para)

commit_message:
Remove duplicate rpc_backend property

When using QPID the rpc_backend property is added twice,
once in line 335 and then again as part of the QPID config.

Change-Id: I1e0ced10709ed9121d7bf6c381c7c4c9005a4dce
